refnamediv.refpurpose: Creates a BRL-CAD combination with the name combination_name.

refsection.title: DESCRIPTION
refsection.para: The comb command creates a BRL-CAD combination with the name combination_name. The r option indicates that the combination is a BRL-CAD region. The c option is the default and indicates that the combination is not a region. The operator/object_name pairs are combinations of boolean operators and object names to be added to the comb.

The w moves the contentions of a combination to a new combination and makes that combination the sole child of the original combination. See the "fixing nested regions" example below for an illustration of how this option is used.

refsection.title: EXAMPLES
refsection.para: This example shows how to use the comb command to create a combination according to a given formula.

term.userinput: comb abc u a u b - a + d

varlistentry.term: Suppose we have a situation where region2.r is unioned into region1.r, and both region1.r and region2.r have the region flag set, as seen in the tree below.

literallayout.computeroutput: mged> tree region1.r region1.r/R u region2.r/R u sph.s u comb.c/ u arb.s

listitem.para:
This geometry has an error in that one region is not supposed to be combined into another using boolean operations. Further, suppose that one or more assemblies use region2.r and expect it to be a region - i.e., region2.r needs to remain a region with the same contents.
To fix this problem without disturbing other geometry using region2.r, first make a combination below region2.r using the w flag to comb:

literallayout.computeroutput: mged> c -w region2.r mged> tree region2.r region2.r/R u region2.r.c/ u sph.s

listitem.para: The next step is to adjust the region1.r tree definition to reference the non-region combination instead of region2.r:

literallayout.computeroutput: mged> set glob_compat_mode 0 0 mged> get region1.r tree u {l region2.r} {l comb.c} mged> adjust region1.r tree {u {l region2.r.c} {l comb.c}} mged> tree region1.r region1.r/R u region2.r.c/ u sph.s u comb.c/ u arb.s

listitem.para: Because the tree is manipulated as a Tcl list, we need glob compatibility mode to be off on the MGED command line. Once the tree is re-defined, region1.r no longer has region2.r below it, but still defines the same physical volume via region2.r.c.
Optionally, the name region2.r.c can be changed to the name region2.c with the mvall command:

literallayout.computeroutput: mged> mvall region2.r.c region2.c mged> tree region1.r region1.r/R u region2.c/ u sph.s u comb.c/ u arb.s mged> tree region2.r region2.r/R u region2.c/ u sph.s
